dialogues.text: Madge walks up the gravel path towards the magnificent building. She's superbly dressed, looks great. She goes up to the BARMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Would there be any wealthy single men in tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is one. Madge puts some money into his breast pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you could seat me next to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, madam. He leads her along across the terrace. Madge follows, checking her hair, her breath, etc. The barman reaches an ornate suite of furniture. There's someone sitting there, his back to us, an elegant arm draped over the side of the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Royal Highness Prince Michael of Kent. The man rises from his chair and turns. And Madge is left staring at Norman. There's a pause. Then Madge reaches into the barman's breast pocket, and removes her money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have that back, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham comes through the courtyard, heads for his room. Muriel is on her verandah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. Muriel nods at him, and he goes on into his room. A moment later, Jean sits down next to Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where he goes. I know you know. But you won't tell me. Muriel says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get Hobnobs out here, you know. I know a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As many as you want. Milk or plain. Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Public Records Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge construction, centuries old, with a series of step reaching down deep into the earth, so people can climb do to get their water. Young couples sit on the steps in the evening heat, boys leap into the water. Sonny and Sunaina are watching the swimmers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father used to bring me to this well to swim. He said the water was better, and so were the people we would meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would have liked you so much. Sunaina smiles at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother doesn't want us to be married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hasn't met me yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't need to meet you Sunaina absorbs this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows you are not from Delhi. That you have no family money, and work in a call centre. You are a part of a new India she cannot welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't this where you tell her what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That conversation will be easier when the hotel is a success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have found a new investor. I am most optimistic that he will enable us to move forward with Phase Two of the Marigold Hotel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you finish Phase One first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In business, if you stand still, you move backwards. No, I have that wrong. If you stand still, you are overtaken by people going the other way. Wait -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't answer the question. Do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My feelings for you cannot be reduced to a single word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a nice word, Sonny. And people like hearing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina, please. My mother is wrong. It is you who are too good for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say that a lot. You shouldn't I'll start to believe you. They watch the boys in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madge and Norman are sitting together. Norman is looking across at the bar, where an attractive older ex-pat lady sitting, thus far resisting Norman's attempts to catch he eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still think you're cramping my style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. You have no style to cramp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That lady at the bar keeps looking at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As one would something in a museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why must you mock? I just want to feel young again, to be needed as much as I need, if only for one night, one wonderful night. Tell me you don't know how that feels.
Silence for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a minute. Then join us. She gets up, heads towards the bar. Where she sits a couple of seats away from the woman. Who is called CAROL. She sits there a moment, then sighs, and starts to talk t the barman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rejected again. Many years ago, that man over there gave me the most extraordinary night of my life. He may seem coarse and uncouth, but that only disguises a tenderness and an exquisite sensitivity to a woman's needs Norman arrives at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those drinks not ready yet? Madge turns to Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say patience is passion tamed. Carol smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Madge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this . is Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol? As in Christmas? Madge winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what brings you to Jaipur, Carol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Carol. What brings you to Jaipur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I run a small boutique travel agency. But I've actually lived here all my life. My father worked in the Foreign Office. Another silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean you look like you keep yourself in shape. Physically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I did join a gym last year. It cost a fortune, and I didn't get any fitter. Apparently you have to actually go. Madge laughs. Norman doesn't. Then realizes that it was a joke, lets out a too-loud bray of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so what do you do, Norman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman's in business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Import-Export.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although these days there's rather more Ex- than Im-, if you see what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I don't. Madge gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to splash some water on my face. Please God I drown in it. She heads for the bathroom. Norman and Carol share another silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well look, it's been lovely chatting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it hasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It hasn't. But I really

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol? She was about to go, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we drop all this pretence? And start again? I'm not charming. I'm not good at repartee. And I'm not a plutocrat with the sexual capacity of a rutting rhino. My name is Norman. And I'm lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Carol. So am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minutes later. Madge comes out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Day 22. Like Darwin's finches, we are slowly adapting to our environment. And when one does adapt, my god, the riches that are available. Madge looks across the bar. And is startled to see Norman and Carol chatting up a storm, laughing together. As she watches, Norman orders more drinks, then turns smiling back to his new friend. Madge walks slowly out of the bar, and into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn is at her computer, typing.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There is no past that we can bring back by longing for it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajit is pushing Muriel down to the gate for her morning constitutional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . only a present that builds and creates itself as the past withdraws ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jay is counting out cash into Evelyn's hand; her first paycheck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And India, like so many things in life, like life itself I suppose, is about what you bring to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajit is pushing Muriel through a poor neighborhood. Murie is looking left and right, astounded by the life she sees

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's this? Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janta Colony Kachi Basti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to my usual route?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anokhi has invited you to her home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd have said no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean is sitting, reading a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you check in at the bank? Douglas emerges from the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I checked yesterday. And the day before. As requested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be staying in again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you ask that every morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I hope for a different answer. Because I think you'll be hurt if I don't. And because it's not healthy for you to spend all day and every day in the confines of the hotel. He goes back into the bathroom. Jean changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't sleep a wink. The tap in there never stops dripping.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I talked to Young Wasim about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: No idea. It was in Hindi. Douglas comes out of the bathroom, holding the tap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I might get it fixed myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time like the present. Actually I say that, but I enjoyed yesterday, and I'm optimistic about tomorrow too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could say the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I. He goes. Jean sits for a while, looking utterly disconsolate and lost. Then she gets up, goes over to the balcony. Down below she can see Graham leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madge is sitting on a chair. Norman arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Madgesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gather the night went well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to hear about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in the least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Because you're going to. Two drinks, some sexually charged

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas comes out, carrying a tap. And heads out of the archway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. Lovely day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. They watch him leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two drinks, some sexually charged banter, and we were heading back to her place. Bidding the rickshaw farewell, I walked her to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there, my young friend, I leaned forward, and I kissed her. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all? You didn't seal the deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a date next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to prolong the anticipation. To spend some time with the knowledge that soon I'm going to eat, drink, and laugh with someone, hold her to me, kiss her softly. Then go back to her place and get my end away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The market is buzzing with commerce. Evelyn is at a stall selling fabrics, talking to the vendor, AKRAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up a pashmina) Bow much for this, please Kitna

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thousand rupees Ek hazaar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. She reaches for her wallet. Then Douglas speaks from behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, forgive me. That's not how it works.

dialogues.speaker: 65A.
dialogues.text: Evelyn turns, happy to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to you. Sorry to butt in, but you don't ask him how much he wants, you just tell him how much you'll pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll give you two hundred. Absolutely no more, final offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thousand rupees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now walk away. Walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I'm doing. Evelyn complies, and they turn and walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The thing is, you see, I did actually want to buy that. To brighten up my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll come after us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. This is how the game is played. Just keep on walking. They push through the crowds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's playing it cool, but he'll come. They keep walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's playing it very cool. They keep walking. Then Douglas stops. Evelyn looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. They're back at Akram's stall. Evelyn counts out the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight hundred and fifty, nine hundred, nine hundred and fifty, one thousand. She turns to Douglas, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get him next time. Then she notices something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you carrying a tap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean gives up on the sentence she has already read a hundred times, and snaps her book shut. She stands, then sits again. Then stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajit is now pushing Muriel through a poverty-stricken slu The people live on the streets, or in collapsing tin shacks. Everywhere there is struggle and deprivation. And yet the pervasive atmosphere is nowhere near as depressing as we would expect. The colours are bright, th smiles on the children's faces even brighter. Not that Muriel can recognise the joy, of course. She's horrified by her surroundings. And acutely aware of the stares of the slum-dwellers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A primitive brick and cement hut, one of the few amongst dwellings made mostly from sticks and plastic bags. A bunch of young kids are fascinated by Muriel's wheelchair, pushing it around and taking turns to sit on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel sits on the only chair. Opposite - squashed together as if posing for a photograp are all the generations of Anokhi's family: Anokhi hersel her husband, mother, grandmother, and several children. They all smile at Muriel. A long pause. Then Muriel turns to Ajit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon can I leave?

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. HARDWARE SHOP
dialogues.text: Douglas is talking to JAMSHED, who works behind the counter. Evelyn sits outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see what I think, and of course I'm no expert, is that the valve seat has eroded, so we'll need the washer changed and a new seat re-ground. Douglas glances back at Evelyn. Who betrays not the slightest scepticism. Jamshed studies the tap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gland nut has come away from the spindle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well of course, it could be that too. Can you fix it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not cheaply. Not cheaply. Most expensively indeed. Jamshed takes the tap to a workstation at the back, start to fiddle with it. Douglas joins Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in a tuk-tuk the other day, didn't seem to be taking the usual route back to the hotel. It turned out that the driver had decided to take me to another hotel, that he was sure I would prefer. And of course one wants to believe that he genuinely had my welfare at heart, and that it wasn't run bg his brother-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One wants to trust, in general, don't you think? But you never really know, do you? Jamshed stops fiddling with the tap. And takes a hammer t it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day I met my husband was the day the fair came to town. My girlfriend and I went on the carousel. Her horse was fine. But when the ride began I felt mine give a little, like it might collapse. Then these strong arms were around me, holding the horse together. And a voice in my ear said "Just trust me". And I did. Without question. Until the day he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sale of our flat went through last week. I had to sell it to pay off Hugh's debts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been forced to get a job out here. Which, in fact, I love. But even at Sonny's rates, I still couldn't make ends meet. After what my own husband did to our life savings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So no. You're right. You never know. Jamshed holds up the tap. Which is now in several parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No good. You must be buying another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean walks down the path to the gate. She stops, looks fearfully at the chaotic sea of humanity outside. She's unable to move. Finally, she steps out. And is of course immediately assaulted by the assorted kids, beggars, street vendors, etc. As anxiety begins to engulf her, she quickens her pace, brushing through them as best she can, until she is almos running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel is still at the tea party. Anokhi speaks. Ajit translates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to thank you for your kindness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the only one that acknowledges her. Anokhi brings out a plate of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tarkha dhal. Chapati.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not eating that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will insult her very deeply if you do not. Muriel looks up. They're all still watching, waiting smiling. She looks at Anokhi's grandmother, as dignified as she is old. Muriel reaches out, takes something off the tray. And has a bite. It's not too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd still rather a Scotch Egg. Then she sees something through the open doorway: the children have turned her wheelchair on its side and are spinning the wheels. She's on her feet in a flash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off! Get off it, you dirty thieving bastards! Several terrified faces turn. One little girl starts to cry. Everyone is staring at Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see. They were playing. I'm sorry. I'm sorry

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean is now in a tuk-tuk, lurching and weaving through th traffic, a handkerchief clasped firmly over her mouth, panic in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JAIPUR
dialogues.text: The corridors are full of people patiently waiting their turn to grapple with a vast bureaucracy. Reaching the top of the staircase, Jean takes it all in. She walks down another corridor. Then stops. Through a doorway, she sees Graham at the desk, talking t Mr Chidambram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've filled out that form. I've given it to you. Many times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a process. You are making an enquiry. For each enquiry a form must be filled in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's the same enquiry I make every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And therefore the same form you must fill in. Graham glances towards the doorway, catches sight of Jean Their eyes lock, then Jean pulls back out of sight, panicked.

dialogues.speaker: 104A INT.CORRIDOR, PUBLIC RECORDS OFFICE. JAIPUR
dialogues.text: Jean is hurrying down a corridor. Behind her, Graham emerges from a doorway, and calls to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Ainslie... .?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Jean and Graham are sitting in an elegant tea room Jean is still very shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how you can bear this country. What do you see that I don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unutterable beauty. Everywhere. In the light, the colours, the smiles, the people who see life as a privilege not a right, and so teach me something every day. The waiter brings their tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this milk pasteurized?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not true, is it? You're just lying to me right now

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be fine. The waiter goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pleasant surprise to see you out and about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it? She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That's progress. Where were you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the bank. I . was going to the bank. Not that there's any reason to think something has changed. But our daughter, you see, she did promise, and one does try to remain optimistic. One has to. Otherwise

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham worries she might be about to break down. He reaches across the table, puts his hand on hers. She leans forward, puts her other hand over his, holds on tightly. Graham is startled. He tries gently to pull back, but she holds on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god. Is it possible you feel the same? She brings his hand to her mouth, kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way you talk to me. Your compassion, your understanding .. the wonderful, tender consideration, it had to be more than just -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gay. She stares at him. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As in ... happy? Graham says nothing. Jean lets go of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I see. Of course I see. The ghastly inappropriateness of it all settles on them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appear to have humiliated myself. And embarrassed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not embarrassed. Jean smiles wanly, grateful for his lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said. This country is driving me mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. DOUGLAS AND JEAN'S ROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL
dialogues.text: Evelyn is outside in the courtyard. We don't see Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Not yet. Evelyn waits a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about now?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: One second. Another pause. DOUGLAS (O.S.) (cont'd) Oh good lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Listen. The sound of a flowing tap. DOUGLAS (O.S.) (cont'd) And now ... The tap stops. DOUGLAS (O.S.) (cont'd) No drip. He appears in the doorway, triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No drip! He walks towards her, hand in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi-five ! Evelyn just looks at him. She's never hi-fived anyone in her life. After a moment Douglas puts his hand down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never done that before. It just seemed appropriate. Jean has appeared at the other side of the courtyard. Douglas senses her mood, moves towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Ainslie, how are you? Did you have a good day? Jean doesn't answer. She's staring at Douglas. Who looks so happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you about ours. Your husband of many a year, who has never even known which end of a hammer to use, has actually managed to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stay in this country a moment longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why ...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do excuse me. She makes a tactful exit. Jean is going past Douglas into their room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick a reason. Pick ten. The climate, the squalor, the poverty She goes past him into their room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . we should never have come. This whole trip is a grotesque fantasy. It's time to go home. Jean starts to pack. Irrationally, compulsively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's paying for the tickets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not hearing him) Look at us. A group of self- deluding old fossils traipsing around as if it's our bloody gap year. Humiliating ourselves

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not us, we can't pay. And I don't see you asking our friends

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .. We should just face up to the truth. That we're all old, we're all past it. That's the real truth, the raw, unvarnished fact of the matter. All we're good for now is the beige bloody bungalow with the sodding panic button in the sodding corner ... She stops packing, and subsides onto the bed, crying quietly. Nobody speaks for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just have to make the best of it, darling. I really think that's the best thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well. When I want your opinion, I'll give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impossibly small roadside clinic. Norman is sitting there, the only man in three rows of brightly dressed women. DR RAMA comes out of the consulting area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr John Smith. No response. The doctor looks at Norman, who has forgotte his own alias. DR RAMA (cont'd) Mr John Smith? Norman jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right! Me!

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. MARKET/OPERATIONS ROOM. CALL CENTRE
dialogues.text: Sonny is at the flower market, sitting on his motor bike, waiting for the flower vendor to tie up his bundle of marigolds. He's on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Pick up pick up pick up. The phone is answered at the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina, I must see you. I must. If I cannot hold your body against mine, I swear I will go mad. We cut to the call centre. It's not Sunaina on the phone, but Jay, who is standing next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I yearn for you, I burn for you,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's my sister you're burning for there, Sonny boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jay. Thank you. Jay hands the phone to Sunaina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private line, Sunaina. Do those words mean nothing to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He took the phone. What could I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss you. I miss you every moment. Come and see me. Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot tonight. It is my parents 25th wedding anniversary. Tell your mother that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come after. Come late

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be asleep. But i can wake you in that special way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will sneak in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither am I. Absolutely not. There is no shame. You do not have to sneak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the same, if you did want to be very quiet, and not let anyone see you, it couldn't hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is talking to DR RAMA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worried there's no lead in my pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. I don't know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No snap in my celery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still not quite with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I plan to party hearty tonight, but I can't guarantee that my love gun will fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Smith -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will the lance dance, and the trouser lion roar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I can still have sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a young man anymore, doctor. And I'm a little bit scared. Truth be told, I'm a lot scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long since you've been with a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some pills that'll help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back of the hotel, where Sonny envisages his Phase Tw development. Very dilapidated. Anokhi is cleaning pots. Young Wasim sits in the corner. Ajit has just wheeled Muriel into the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to tell you something... Anokhi looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her. Tell her I was glad to come, glad she invited me. Ajit translates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to meet her family. Her grandmother. Her kids. Ajit translates. Anokhi speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She asks if you have children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked after somebody else's. Ajit translates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one family, years I was with them. I ran the house, looked after the money, did it all, cared for them like they were my own. Ajit starts to translate. But Muriel doesn't wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the mistake, see. You don't want to get like that, to start feeling part of something. One day they decided I needed some help. I was grateful, I tried to teach her. Not just the books, but how to crisp up the bacon like the gentleman preferred it, the way the little one liked to have her hair brushed. The things you only know if you care. But then they said I was no longer useful to them. Thanked me for my service. As if that's all it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a flat in the end. I'm the only one in the building not a foreigner. More Indians there than here! But before I came to this place, my biggest problem was what to do with all the time I had. Because that flat's so small, I can have the whole place spotless in half an hour. And then what am I supposed to do for the rest of the day? There's silence for a bit. Then Ajit speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you want me translate that as well? Muriel smiles. It's the first time we've seen this. Muriel stops, thrusts something into Ajit's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give her these.

Ajit hands Anokhi what Muriel gave him: a packet of Chocolate Hobnobs. This time it's Muriel who cannot meet Anokhi's eye. Tries to hide her desire to leave. Ajit turns her chair and pushes her away. Over this, the sound of singing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman's on his rooftop, under the primitive spout of wat that passes as his shower. Hanging from a nail in the wal the battery radio is pumping out a bizarre Indian cover version of the Chic song "Le Freak". Norman is naked, and singing along lustily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaaaaah, freak out! Le freak, c'est chic .. Aaaah, freak out! Feet slapping in the soapy water, he performs a nifty dis move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny is in his office, going through the accounts. There's a strange ringing somewhere nearby. He pays no attention, then stops and thinks for a moment. Then realises what it is. He sweeps the pile of papers off the desk, starts frantically looking for the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham and Evelyn are having drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been getting out and about as much as I can, but I feel I've hardly scratched the surface. And of course I'd love to see Udaipur. The lake you talked about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to take you. Perhaps - He breaks off. Douglas and Jean have come in. Jean looks rather desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: 81A.
dialogues.text: An awkward moment. Graham stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mrs Ainslie. Please allow me. He pulls a chair out for her. She shoots him a look of passionate gratitude for his exquisite sensitivity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very kind. But I rather think I'll turn in early. Goodnight everyone. She goes into her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel is sitting outside her room, doing the crossword. Madge is coming through the arch, stops dead. Norman is standing in front of her, on his way out. He looks transformed. And rather handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not worried about the danger of having sex at your age? Norman shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she dies, she dies. He leaves. Sonny sprints into the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Progress, Mrs Donnelly, Mrs Hardcastle! The wheel is turning most assuredly in our favour! He shoots up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas, Graham and Evelyn are looking at the menu. Sonny bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Dashwood! Everybody! Great news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Sonny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are working, they are working!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is great news. What are working?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephones of the Marigold Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I must tell everybody. I must tell my mother! He runs off. Comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh wait. You have a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham, Evelyn, and Douglas are walking quickly up a quie street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a false alarm. There's no way they could find anything in that office. They probably just picked an address at random, just to keep me off their backs. I'm sure that's what happened. It's going to be nothing. Don't you think it's going to be nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should knock on the door and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes I should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some men sit under a tree, playing cards.
Across the street, Graham approaches a house. At a polite distance, Evelyn and Douglas wait. Graham knocks at the open door. A woman, GAURIKA, appears. She stares at Graham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to disturb you so late. My name is Graham Dashwood. A long time ago I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who you are. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am afraid I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Gaurika. The wife of Manoj.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a fraction of a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very pleased to meet you. And if you could, if you would tell him that I called around, I'd appreciate that very much,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off. She's walked past him, looking to the othe side of the road. He turns to look at the men playing cards. Gaurika calls Hindi. A beautiful-looking man looks up. MANOJ. He looks across at the house. Stands up slowly as Graham walks across the street towards him. Graham reaches him. The two men just stand there for a moment. Then they hug very tightly. From the steps of the house, Gaurika watches. Evelyn looks at her, fascinated. Across the street, Manoj and Graham are still holding eac other, unable to let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas and Evelyn are walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a tiny bit sloshed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time going in to London with my dad, on his commute... He'd always been so extraordinary to me, so unique. But there he was standing on the station platform, utterly indistinguishable from all the other men in suits. And then of course a few years later I was one of them... Hated my job. Hated it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, talking too much. Blame a good dinner out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was she thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife. Manoj's wife. She knew who Graham was. Had he told her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you think we'll find out tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me, I'm heading up to the Badi Mahal Palace. Very excited, been reading all about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would, if I could remember a word. Evelyn laughs. Then Douglas suddenly grabs her. And pulls her out of the way of a motor bike, zooming past them. Sunaina hasn't realised she nearly hit them, and powers o towards the Marigold. Douglas and Evelyn stand for a moment, startled, holding each other. Something passes between them that embarrasse them both. Then they part quickly, guiltily. They're outside a small restaurant, and with exquisite timing, a group of musicians start to play a romantic tun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, please. Nice meal, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've eaten, thank you... They continue on their way. Slightly further apart than before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the middle of the night, and everything's quiet Or as quiet as it can be in the middle of the usual night-ti Indian cacophony. Sunaina parks her bike outside the hotel, goes on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny is sleeping peacefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina moves across the courtyard. Not sneaking, exactly. But making no sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny sleeps on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina is definitely sneaking now. She aims down the passage towards Sonny's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny stirs, but doesn't wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina comith esno te bedroom. She takes off her clothes. And climbs, naked, into bed beside the sleeping figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud scream. In a different bed, in a different room, Sonny wakes up. And remembers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Sunaina that's screamed. Because she's in bed with Madge. Who couldn't be happier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A midnight booty call. How utterly marvellous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny hares out of his temporary bedroom, and races down the corridor, towards Madge's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina has jumped out of the bed and across the room, grabbing one of Madge's generous scarves to cover her nakedness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, I'm so sorry . I don't know what your name is, but I'm incredibly sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be. Most action I've had in weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could just please not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not worry, Mrs Hardcastle! I can explain each and every thing! Hesees Sunaina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god you are naked. He turns to Madge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Hardcastle, I must apologise with deep and profound sincerity -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you not tell me you weren't in your room!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sunaina, to you too I must apologise with equally deep and profound sincerity. Now go. Get out. Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going. Just let me get dressed, and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, quicker than that. You must leave, before - MrsKapoor flings open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is going on here? Who screamed? She sees the nearly-naked Sunaina. MRS KAPOOR (cont'd) No no no no no. No! This is a respectable hotel, not a brothel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Mrs Hardcastle, I expected better of you. Actually, this is exactly what I expected of you, but nevertheless -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Kapoor, I'm Sunaina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I will not be paying for your services, your name is of no interest to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know mine? Sunaina is shocked to realise that Mrs Kapoor doesn't kno her name. Sonny steps forward reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because this . is my Sunaina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl who my son described as not too modern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is getting interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, please.
MRS KAPOOR (cont'd) Is there anyone in this building you haven't slept with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummyji, do not get the wrong idea. Sunaina was not here to be with Mrs Hardcastle. She was here to have sex with me! Mrs Kapoor turns to Sunaina. Who is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the sort of woman you are. OK. Each to her own. But do not ever try and tell me that you are suitable wife for my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find your clothes and go. I don't expect to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina is leaving the hotel, angry and humiliated. Evely and Douglas are coming up the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina? And now Sunaina is even more humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina roars away on her scooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same street. The sun is just coming up, and traders a setting up their stalls, spreading their wares on rugs on the ground. One trader is unloading some fruit. A few guava roll off the edge of his wagon. Someone picks them up for him. It's Graham, who smiles as he puts them back. The trader gives him a fresh one. Graham takes it, and walks on, munching the delicious fruit. A contented man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is sitting on a stone bench under a spreading tree

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: How did it go? Norman turns, to see Graham standing above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have seen the top of the mountain. And it is good. Graham nods, sits down next to him. They gaze out at the waking city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw someone yesterday, a man I hadn't seen for many years. A man I've loved all my life. Norman is a bit startled by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man... .?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carry on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, unperturbed) I didn't know how he'd been in the meantime, didn't want to guess. I brought disgrace upon him and his family, and imagined he might hate me for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we talked all night. He's been happy. He's led a peaceful life, married to a woman who understood him and loved him nonetheless. But he's never forgotten me. That's what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked his forgiveness anyway. He said he had nothing to forgive me for. That instead I should forgive myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that time. All that time I believed I'd sentenced him to a life of shame. When I was the one in prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not any more.
Silence for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top of the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Norman smiles, then stands and goes on inside. Graham settles back into his chair, looks out at the worl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman comes into the courtyard. Madge, sipping from a cu of chai, calls down from her verandah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was the night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather special. He leaves. Madge just stares after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman on the stairs to his room. He stops, catches his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham is watching a stunningly beautiful bird. A snow crane; white and magnificent. It's on the grass in front of him. Then it opens its huge wings, takes off. And flies up int the bright blue sky. It's an extraordinary sight. As Graham watches the snow crane swoop and dip, it appear suddenly to slow and stall, until it seems to hang in the air, almost motionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman crosses the rooftop to his bedroom. He comes inside, sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham is still sitting in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: You're back. He doesn't turn round. Evelyn has come out to the garden. She goes over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been rather an extraordinary night all round. First tell me your news, and then - She breaks off. Graham is dead.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Day 45. Of course it was inevitable. Put enough old people in the same place, it won't be too long before one of them goes... Jean, Douglas, Madge, Norman and Muriel shocked and sober

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train is crossing the endless fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn stares out of the window. Madge, Norman, Douglas and Jean are behind her. Opposite sits Manoj. Evelyn turns to look at him, and at Gaurika, Manoj's wife, who sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We all know it'll happen, but few of us know when. Graham died of a heart attack, evidently not his first. So he had a better idea than most what was coming, he just neglected to tell us. His prerogative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three white vehicles are driving across a narrow causeway which barely rises above the surface of the lake. They seem to be floating. Clouds of dust billow behind them.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There was talk of sending the body home, but Manoj felt he should have a Hindu burial. At the place they had visited together. Not a holy place. Although for them perhaps it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ruined garden, surrounded by the waters of the lake, crumbling pillared porticoes and arches. What must once have been a royal retreat is now long abandoned and overgrown. Graham's friends stand watching the pyre, transfixed by t flames. Manoj, dressed in white, stands with Gaurika. He recites a Hindi prayer.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A body takes a long time to be consumed. Many hours for the mourners to remember their dead. The fire must be lit at dawn, and by sunset, there must be nothing left but ash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stripped to the waist, Manoj walks into the water, holdin a bowl.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Where do our souls go? is that all of us that is left behind? Perhaps the most we can ask is that when we do shuffle off, we do so knowing that we were loved Manoj pours Graham onto the water. The ashes shim r and dance, caught in the gentle currents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel and Anokhi are in the servants' garden. Young Wasi sits silently in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there's a process, they call it pickling. I have no idea what it is, or how they do it, but whoever invented it was a smart man. But the real genius was the one who introduced an onion into the system. That I could never have thought of.
Ajit looks at her, ready to translate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, forget it. Muriel is looking out at the yard. She sees Mrs Kapoor, talking to some surveyors. They're mapping out the building. Mrs Kapoor sees Muriel watching her, comes over to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Donnelly, what are you doing here? You should not be here, talking with this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm helping her clean. If these pots get any dirtier, you'll have to serve the food with penicillin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have other rooms. Go to one of them instead. While this is still a hotel. She turns back to the surveyors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her problem? What's happening here? Ajit can't answer. But he knows a man who can. He points to Young Wasim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stunning view over the city. Madge is having a drink with Norman. Douglas is sitting on the wall, but keeps looking down towards the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When someone dies, you think about your own life. And in my case, there is less of it in front of me than behind. And I don't want to grow older. I don't want to be condescended to, ignored and marginalised by society. To become peripheral to the action.
MADGE (coat' d) I don't want to be the first person let off the plane in a hostage crisis. They laugh together. And don't even see Douglas go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The landing is large, and open to the sky. Evelyn has jus come up the stairs to go to her room. She's leaning again the stone baluster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered where you'd been. Evelyn turns. Douglas is on the stairs above her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all up top, having a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to see Gaurika. Manoj's wife. I wanted to ask her what she knew. And the answer was that she knew everything, that he'd loved another man, and always would. He told her when the marriage was arranged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had no secrets from each other, none. Suddenly she's crying. Unable to stop. Douglas puts his arms around her, and holds her to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's right, don't you see? That must be right. Because what is the point of a marriage in which nothing is shared? Her words hang in the air. They stand there for a moment. Jean has come out of her room, and stands there, watching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Greenslade, might I have my husband back now? They spring apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas? She walks off back into the room. Douglas turns to Evelyn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. Evelyn goes quickly to her room, leaving him standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spare me your explanations. D'you think I'm jealous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see why else you would have embarrassed me. And Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were already doing a perfectly good job of embarrassing yourself. Can you imagine how ghastly it's been for everyone to watch you mooning around after that simpering doe- eyed ex-housewife, taking advantage of her loneliness and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, can you hear yourself? Can you? Do you have any idea what a terrible person you've become? Jean is stunned into silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you give out is this endless negativity, a refusal to see any kind of light and joy even when it's right in your face, and a desperate need to squash any sign of happiness in me or anyone else .. it's a wonder I don't fling myself at the first kind word or gesture that comes my way. But I don't. Out of some dried-out notion of loyalty and respect, neither of which I ever bloody get in return.
There's a long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I checked my emails. This came. She hands him a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn comes onto the terrace, and heads for Madge and Norman. She picks up Madge's glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need some water. She drains the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a gin and tonic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I know that now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, the Ainslies. Douglas and Jean are approaching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you both?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're particularly well. Douglas, tell them our news. She looks to him, waits. He says nothing. So she turns, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny is with his investor, Mr Maruthi. They emerge from the upper courtyard onto the terrace overlooking the back of the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so I would ask you to loosen the strings on your purse, Mr Maruthi, and to do it most rapidly. So that Phase Two Development of the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel can begin with immediate effect. Mr Maruthi looks down, sees Muriel. She's with Anokhi, Ajit, and Young Wasim. He calls down to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Donnelly, I believe. Sonny spots the danger, tries to lead Mr Maruthi away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now if you would please be following me to the ground floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Maruthi ignores him, calls down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are things at the hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Maruthi -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better. They're going better. Sonny takes a moment to recover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see? Profound satisfaction. Such is the inevitable result of a prolonged stay at the Marigold Hotel. And now Mr Maruthi has spotted something else. The surveyors, who are still taking their measurements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are those men doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Glancing back for a moment) Working for me, Mr Maruthi. To create a home for the elderly so wonderful that they will simply refuse to die! Stare death in the face and say-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (follows Mr Maruthi's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are those men doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Through the window, Muriel watches Sonny confronting his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummyji, what is going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have spoken to your brothers. They want to sell the hotel. These men are here to value the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are valuing the land. My brothers do not care about the building. They will knock it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They could just wait a month for it to fall down of its own accord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You joke, Mummyji, but inside I know you are not laughing. You do not want to see this dream destroyed. Send these people away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my son. It is too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Kapoor is at the desk, going through the accounts. Sonny stands opposite her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummyji, please -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These figures do not support your argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is still time to turn things around. With a small injection of funds, we can -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is trusting you with that money? Eh? You, who cannot run a chai stand. Just like your father.
Beat. Then Sonny speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I remind you of him so much? Is that why you must be cruel to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I am cruel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You loved my father. And he loved this hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two mistakes. There will not be a third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say goodbye to all this, Sonny. And come with me to Delhi. Your life will become easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not easier, Mummyji. Smaller. He leaves. Mrs Kapoor comes back to the desk, fiddling with some paperwork, discomfited. She turns to the doorway. Muriel is there, in her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Donnelly. Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends. Do you know how to use a computer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume you are joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Ainslie said she had an address where I could get some things I need. Some biscuits. She said I could get them on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you luck. Mrs Kapoor smiles, and leaves. Muriel watches her go, then turns to the computer. Her fingers fly across the keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train rattles its way through the night. Jean is chatting away, in a better mood than we've seen her for some time. Evelyn listens in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole thing is actually tremendously exciting. Not just getting on a plane, but getting on a plane and turning left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First class. And home in time for our 40th wedding anniversary. We haven't yet decided how to mark the occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps a minute's silence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajit keeps watch, while Muriel is at the printer. Waiting as it disgorges pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tuk-tuks are lined up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hailing a tuk-tuk) Two should fit us all, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm actually going to walk. Apparently they're getting ready for a festival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you'd like one of us to accompany you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy to walk with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be fine. Evelyn speaks to both Douglas and Jean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm delighted for your daughter's success. I wish you all every happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Evelyn turns, and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas and Jean are in the tuk-tuk with Madge and Norman There is a sombre atmosphere. A motor-bike hurtles past them, going the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that Sonny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone is ringing. Christopher is still in bed, his wife Polly asleep next to him. He answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (can't believe his ears) Ma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn stands under the awning of the ticket office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to hear your voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry, I didn't think about the time . How are you? And Polly? The boys . how are the boys? She listens to him. She's holding back tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh good, I'm glad you've been reading it. Yes. Yes, I've made some very good friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine, of course I am.
As much as she had wanted to speak to him, she now wants the conversation to be over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think my money is running out, I'd better go. Goodbye for now, darling. I'll call again later. She hangs up. And stays there with her hand on the phone. Out on the street, Sonny is pulling up. She looks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Greenslade. Where are the others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're on their way to the hotel. Sonny looks around, at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to warn you before you see for yourself of the most momentous changes that are occurring, absolutely all of them without question for the very positive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am delighted to announce the closing of the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel, and the joyful return of all of its inhabitants to their home country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman and Madge have arrived back at the hotel. Mrs Kapoor is breaking the news to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please relax in the knowledge that your journey home is being arranged, and paid for by the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our journey here was arranged and paid for by the hotel, and look how that went. I'd rather walk back to England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather not go back at all. A voice comes behind them. Carol has come out of the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you have to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny and Evelyn are still talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And for myself the news is even better. I shall be moving to Delhi to live with my mother, and furthermore I shall be wed to a most suitable person of her choice, whom I look forward very much to meeting before I spend the rest of my life with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about your girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is no longer my girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we must treat it just the same as we would treat a triumph, is that not what your Mr Kipling tells us? Although of course, here we have a problem. Because I, Sunil Indrajit Kapoor, have never had a triumph, so of course I do not know how to treat one. No, all I have had is an constant series of disasters interspersed with the occasional catastrophe, an unending stream of total -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny, do you love her? Sunaina?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you told her you love her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is because I love her that I must not tell her. She can do so much better than me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you have told her that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Women love it when you say that kind of thing. It's a powerful aphrodisiac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not. Go and find her right now, before you lose her forever. Her future is hers to choose, and so is yours. You can have anything you want, Sonny. You just need to stop waiting for someone to tell you you deserve it. Or you can just keep failing yourself, and hurting the ones you love -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Greenslade, stop drilling! You have struck oil! He goes to his bike, climbs on, and rockets off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madge is sitting, pensive. Carol comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Norman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we don't have to leave yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked him to come and stay with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that wise? I'm not sure he's trained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it's too soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is too soon. But at our age we can't afford the luxury of taking it slow. And it's either this or he goes home and I don't want him to go home. Madge looks at her for a while. Then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you both the very best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't met anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Single by choice. Just not my choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I actually think it might be over. For me. With men. And if that's gone, I'm not quite sure what's left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know Norman brought pills? The first night he stayed with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They obviously did the trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw them in his pocket. I didn't want it to be like that. So when I had the chance I swapped them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went all night on two aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's never over. Norman appears with his one bag and his battery radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny roars through the streets on his bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn approaches. She sees a taxi waiting outside the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The houseboy is carrying Douglas and Jean's bags down to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn comes into the courtyard. Muriel is sitting there. The two women stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want him to see you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny is waiting at a junction, texting into his mobile phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas is checking they haven't left anything. Jean is a the door. She's impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina picks up her mobile, looks at the message.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. TAXI/STREET. MARIGOLD HOTEL
dialogues.text: Jean is sitting in the taxi, which is driven by BARUM. Douglas climbs in. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wallet, I forgot my wallet. One second. Before Jean has a chance to say anything, he goes back in
She watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas comes back into the courtyard, heads towards the staircase to Evelyn's room. Then Muriel speaks from her verandah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not back yet. Douglas stops. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then perhaps you could tell her I said goodbye. He turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn is at her window, listening. She turns to watch hi leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas gets back into the taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slamming the door) False alarm. Had it the whole time. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny roars into the forecourt, gets off his bike, and ru into the building. A SECURITY GUARD goes to stop him, but Sonny's already running up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny keeps going up, floor after floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina! Sunaina! He reaches the seventh floor. Jay appears on the landing above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? Sonny is doubled over, totally out of breath. Holds up a finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to see Sunaina!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her shift's not over. And when it is, she doesn't want to see you. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jay, you are the son my mother wished I was; an intelligent man, with a strong head for business. You see things as they are, not as you wish them to be. So fuck off out of my way. Jaydoesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or you can give her a message. Sunaina is standing against the wall, unseen by Sonny, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her from me what I should have told her the day we met. What I will announce to anyone who asks. And many who do not. Sunaina speaks to Jay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including my mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will tell every mother in the land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will you tell them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will you tell them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing that matters in this world. That I love you. And always will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And by you, I mean Sunaina, Jay, not you. Although if you are to be my brother-in-law, I hope we can become better friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is he only saying this now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you only saying this now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, Sunaina, love of my life, no more will I believe that I am not worthy, for only by loving you as you deserve will I become so. On Sunaina's face as she hears this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cacophonous sound of drumming: a small band of player are beating out a deafening, syncopated rhythm as the Ganeshi festival begins to unfold. Sonny is on his bike, Sunaina riding side-saddle on the back. They're speeding through the city. Sonny rockets through an arch way up a side street, is confronted by a huge traffic jam. The Ganeshi procession bringing everything to a standstill. He does a U-turn, speeds off back the way they came.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TAXI/STREET
dialogues.text: Douglas and Jean are sitting in the traffic jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny. They call it rush hour, but nothing actually moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although I suppose it's all about context, isn't it? I mean -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you say one more word, I'll kill you with my thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel sits alone in the courtyard, under her awning. Then Carol and Norman appear from reception, followed by Mrs Kapoor. They cross towards the arch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where d'you think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may well ask. Madge is sitting under the shade of a tree..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're moving in together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That point has been made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hotel is closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't have to. Silence. Everyone stares at Muriel. She takes out the spreadsheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been going over the accounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anything, the traffic is now worse. Jean and Douglas's taxi has progressed a few yards, and is now wedged into t arch. The Ganeshi procession is completely blocking the f entrance to the archway. Jean gets out, looks at the sea of unmoving traffic ahead and behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. It could go on for hours. There's no way we're ever going to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there is. A rickshaw arrives next to them, swerving through the traffic. It is ridden by IFTI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. Can you get us to the airport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry long way sore legs not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you everything I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step right in mind your head let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Douglas. Come on! Douglas gets the suitcases out of the trunk of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry no manage people and cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing her suitcases) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not possible. Two person, no cases; one person, and cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking off her watch) How about if I give you something else? My watch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Thank you. Still not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get another flight. We can go back to the hotel, and leave in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean, you heard what he said. He can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can do one person, and cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could fate find a better way to tell us what we need to hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That it's over. It was over a long long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not the time to talk about this. Let's wait till we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go, Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't let you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you'll want to come after me. Chase me to the airport and tell me everything will be fine. But please don't. Because the truth is we both deserve more than we've had. You're just too kind and too loyal to admit it.

dialogues.speaker: 113A.
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm turning left. She climbs onto the rickshaw.
As the drumming intensifies, Douglas stands holding his suitcase, watching her weave through the traffic and out sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny and Sunaina roar towards the hotel, drive into the gate and up the path...
