dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Kapoor is studying the spreadsheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what any of these figures mean. Sonny and Sunaina drive into the courtyard, screech to a halt. They dismount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummyji? Mummyjit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here, you do not need to shout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember what my father used to say? That nothing happens unless first we dream. Like him I have dreamt, Mummyji, and like him, I have failed. The Marigold Hotel is crumbling into dust. And it turns out I can live with that. But the one thing I will not do is live without this girl. To whom I did not introduce you properly before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Sunaina Shantanu Palawat. The woman I love, and wish to marry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am very pleased to meet you, Mrs Kapoor.
Sunaina puts out her hand. Mrs Kapoor will not take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) No. I forbid it. I forbid this match. Utterly and completely. Do you hear me, Sonny? This cannot happen. And then a low, rumbling sound comes from the corner. Lik a quiet volcano. Young Wasim is speaking. It's a long, poetic and heartfel speech. Unfortunately it's in Hindi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is he saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What he said to me, I imagine. She turns to Sunaina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is saying . he is saying that he has been with this family as long as he can remember. Given them a lifetime of service. And that he remembers another fight, between two young people and their parents. And he remembers the moment where the young man stood up to his mother

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . and said yes, I want to marry this woman. Yes, she is from a different community. But she is smart, she is beautiful, and I love her. Long pause. MRS KAPOOR (cont'd) I don't know who he's talking about. She offers Sunaina her hand. MRS KAPOOR (cont'd) Take care of my favourite son. Sunaina shakes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm not clear now. Am I staying or going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends how you read the accounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The accounts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns out the original plan is good, it works. Just not in the hands of an imbecile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew that plan was good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the place needs is more money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately my investor, Mr Maruthi has decided that while he greatly admires my endeavors, he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's reconsidered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You spoke to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long as there is someone to help the manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager needs no help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager needs a little help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So will you stay? Norman looks at Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the shack on the roof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sleep in the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a double room. Bathroom ensuite. And a fully working door. He points to Graham's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guest has recently checked out. Madge can't believe he just said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Hardcastle ? You're staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On my own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're off your game. Lost your confidence, maybe. But you're a thoroughbred. You'll be back. Madge smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about you, Mrs Greenslade? Evelyn has come down, unnoticed by all. Except Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me, Mrs Donnelly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't talked much, you and I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My loss, evidently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure what I should do. Nothing here has quite worked out as I hoped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most things don't. But sometimes what happens instead is the good stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you got work in the morning? Evelyn nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, he'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know him. He's the most loyal man I've ever met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50,000 rupees says I'm right. At your current salary that should take you three months to pay off. Muriel stands up. Everybody stares. She starts to walk slowly but proudly across the courtyard. She reaches the doorway, turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll excuse me, someone's waiting to help me make mango chutney. Why did no one tell me about that stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is the new assistant manager?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Are you thinking of applying for the job? She gestures for her wheelchair. Sonny rushes up with it. She sinks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough exercise for one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean sits in the rickshaw, surrounded by her luggage, carried by Ifti's strong legs towards her future.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Day 51. The only real failure is the failure to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn is at her computer typing.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And the measure of success is how we cope with disappointment. As we always must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas, still holding his suitcase, is surrounded by Ganeshi drummers, silhouetted against the lights of the city. The sound fades as he disappears into the celebration, an is replaced by the gentle sound of temple bells, ringing for morning prayers.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We came here, and we tried. All of us, in our different ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn is still sitting, fully dressed in her room. She's been up all night. Her alarm clock buzzes. She turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn comes out of her room, walks across the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Some achieved more than others. but we did our best. Nothing else matters. Evelyn walks through the courtyard, and on out of the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn walks down the path towards the street. Then Douglas comes through the gate, with his suitcase. They stand there, looking at each other for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Jean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting down his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had quite an interesting night, actually. I met the same taxi driver, but this time I let him take me to his brother's hotel. Which turned out to be less of a hotel, and more of a brothel, really. They gave me this pipe, said it was apple tobacco, but that's not what we called it when I was a student. So I made my excuses and left, wanted some time to think. This city at night is extraordinary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course the apple tobacco helped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess what? I finally saw an elephant. Silence for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm late for work. She goes past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um ... She stops, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time do you finish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get back about 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a little milk. She turns and walks away. She's smiling.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Perhaps it's true: we don't stop playing because we grow old, we grow old because we stop playing. Douglas is haggling with a motorbike mechanic. He seems t be having more success with the price than in earlier day

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is lying on Norman's bed, reading a book, while he washes his socks in a bucket.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: All we really know about the future is that it will be different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madge is chatting vivaciously to someone. It's the elegan older man we saw earlier. And he seems utterly smitten.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So we must celebrate the changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny and Sunaina race through the streets on his motorbike. Sonny raises a fist in salute.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Let them come. Bring them on. Because as someone once said, everything will be alright in the end ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming from the other direction, another motorbike, Dougl at the handlebars, returning Sonny's greeting. And on the pillion seat, riding side-saddle, her scarf flying in the breeze, is Evelyn, on her way home from wor EVELYN (V.0.) (cont'd) So if it's really not alright, then trust me: it's not yet the end.
